title: 10 Minutes Gone
review: "10 Minutes Gone" is clumsy and cliché-ridden, and populated by two accomplished action stars who look like they just want to get through this job as quickly as possible.

title: 10 Minutes Gone
review: Wearing the same pained expression the actor adopts for most of these low-budget features, Willis seems to grimace through every scene only as long as necessary to collect a paycheck.

title: 10 Minutes Gone
review: The title of this movie proves unusually apt: You will figure out its climactic plot twist within the first 10 minutes.

title: 10 Minutes Gone
review: Now, if there was something winkingly camp about 10 Minutes Gone, it might be modestly viable entertainment. But it takes itself just seriously enough to render it flavorless mush...

title: 10 Minutes Gone
review: 10 Minutes Gone starts out with most of a gang planning a heist and discussing it in a bar over beers and whiskey (the best way to plan heists, naturally), and shortly after, it's difficult to determine what gets clumsier, the heist or the movie itself.

title: 10 Minutes Gone
review: Works through as many cliches as possible in 90 minutes.

title: Armor
review: Neither its staging nor its performances transcend the limitations of Adrian Speckert and Cory Todd Hughes’ script, leaving mediocre material unredeemed by any special thrills, style, or character detailing.

title: Armor
review: Even at its relatively trim 89-minute runtime, "Armor" feels padded.

title: Armor
review: Jason Patric and Sylvester Stallone still have solid screen presence and deserve much better than movies like Armor. Avoid this one unless you want to see many people talk through a wall between intermittent explosions and gunfire.

title: Armor
review: Stallone reportedly shot his entire role in one day. The rest of the film feels shot in the second.

title: Armor
review: A repetitive, tedious action “romp”, full of terrible digital effects and clichéd characterisations, and lacking in anything resembling excitement or tension. Armor is, unfortunately, a wasted opportunity.

title: Armor
review: There are simply too many better action films to spend your time on Armor.

title: Arthur and the Great Adventure
review: The narration is somewhat muddled, the special effects are almost endearingly nave, and I cannot see who it's aimed at.

title: Arthur and the Great Adventure
review: One life-threatening, story-aggregating episode follows another so that, long before the film ends, you wish Arthur and his chums would have a lie down.

title: Arthur and the Great Adventure
review: While adults may well be fumbling for paracetamol after a few minutes, their offspring may well love its sugar-rush energy. But it could easily have lost a third of its length with little difference.

title: Arthur and the Great Adventure
review: This is nicely acted and Besson deserves some sort of award for casting Lou Reed and Iggy Pop as its villains, but the script and direction are all over the place and it never really comes together.

title: Arthur and the Great Adventure
review: Even those generous enough to have rescued 2007's part-animated Arthur and the Invisibles from a DVD bargain bin would likely concede there wasn't much call for a sequel.

title: Arthur and the Great Adventure
review: The weird structure of this movie - the first in a two-part series - means the narrative unfolds at a strange pace with Maltazard only making his appearance well into the film and the story ending abruptly.

title: Any Day
review: A well-intentioned disaster, only slightly redeemed by a committed performance by Sean Bean, whose talent proves nowhere near enough to make this manipulative tripe more digestible.

title: Any Day
review: A clich-ridden, heavy-handed redemptive drama written and directed by Rustam Branaman.

title: Any Day
review: Branaman's script piles on low-level drama, bad decisions, and enough misdirection to make the film's baffling ending feel not just unearned, but entirely unbelievable.

title: Any Day
review: An earnest, utterly predictable indie that wastes a couple of decent performances in service of a hackneyed and weak script ...

title: Any Day
review: Everything in Any Day is portentous and presented as if it is loaded with meaning; none of it is, because everything is either so obvious or so arbitrary that nothing actually means anything.

title: Any Day
review: Any Day falls into the painfully crowded trough between not-bad and seriously not-good movies.

title: Arjun Patiala
review: Arjun Patiala feels like a Punjabi film masquerading as a Bollywood one. The humour is deliberately rough and rustic and the filmmaking clunky.

title: Arjun Patiala
review: Varun Sharma repeats his buffoon act and Kriti Sanon reprises her pretty small-town girl role. Both deliver been-there-seen-that performances.

title: Arjun Patiala
review: A feature-length comedy that somehow manages to embody all the lazy stereotypes it makes fun of...

title: Arjun Patiala
review: More was expected from the film but it just doesn't aim high enough. To cut a long story short, the ingredients are all there but the execution isn't up to mark.

title: Arjun Patiala
review: The film is way too aimless a ride to give an audience looking for genuine humour the feeling that its purpose is in with a real chance of being served.

title: Arjun Patiala
review: Spoof comedies can be a tricky affair and this one is way too underwhelming to tickle your funny bone for full two hours.

title: Armed Response
review: Snipes, for his part, looks bored off his rocker. He barely gets to move, and spends most of the movie looking like he's making to-do lists in his head.

title: Armed Response
review: "Armed Response" has less story than your average first-person shooter video game - and far fewer moments of exciting action or nerve-wracking suspense as well.

title: Armed Response
review: The possibilities are intriguing, but the characters are underdrawn, and the pacing lags.

title: Armed Response
review: Armed Response has all the hallmarks of a film that was never fully thought through, and was made on a whim once some rogue investors misguidedly threw some money at the project.

title: Armed Response
review: Armed Response doesn't deserve a response for how bad it is, but you should know before you choose to see it.

title: Armed Response
review: Unless there's a burning need to see Gene Simmons without hair (it's actually a good look), this is a movie about a prison that feels like prison.

title: Andròn -- The Black Labyrinth
review: If it were at all original, "Andron" would be merely a bad movie poorly executed. That it is instead a knockoff of "The Hunger Games" and "The Maze Runner" makes it all the more condemnable.

title: Andròn -- The Black Labyrinth
review: The hapless viewer who has stumbled upon this cheesy knockoff will likely feel trapped right along with the wooden performances and plodding plot.

title: Andròn -- The Black Labyrinth
review: It all gets ponderous, especially all the vague political machinations.

title: Andròn -- The Black Labyrinth
review: Andron is as derivative as it sounds...

title: Andròn -- The Black Labyrinth
review: Because this is world-building at its flimsiest, it fails almost completely.

title: Andròn -- The Black Labyrinth
review: Lack of engaging characters won't play well to the target audience.

title: Assault on VA-33
review: It's quite distracting in its shabbiness.

title: Assault on VA-33
review: ... it's these details which make Assault memorable, offering a bit more pathos to an otherwise predictable adventure tale.

title: Assault on VA-33
review: It is just another entry in the military glorification canon, offering nothing else and little enough of that.

title: Assault on VA-33
review: Remarkably unadventurous for a "Die Hard" knockoff, missing a vital level of building movement and physical exertion to provide any of the thrills the subgenre is capable of delivering.

title: American Pie Presents: The Naked Mile
review: A typically worthless straight-to-video American Pie sequel...

title: American Pie Presents: The Naked Mile
review: Another raunchy race toward the first time; adults only.

title: American Pie Presents: The Naked Mile
review: I don't know who's out there buying the American Pie video sequels, but I sure do wish they'd stop.

title: American Pie Presents: The Naked Mile
review: Crude, sure. Vulgar, no doubt. But funny? Not at all.

title: American Pie Presents: The Naked Mile
review: I never thought I'd believe that the characters in American Pie were rich and nuanced, but compared to the disjointed, half-written affair here, they may as well be from Shakespeare.

title: An Invisible Sign
review: Agrelo clumsily attempts to play jaunty larkiness against somber situations.

title: An Invisible Sign
review: Alba certainly tries her best at portraying not just a beauty but also a beautiful mind, yet very few things add up despite director Marilyn Agrelo's efforts.

title: An Invisible Sign
review: The film is a puzzling mix of sentiment, black humor, and loads and loads of nonsensical behavior.

title: An Invisible Sign
review: ...a plodding, consistently tedious waste of time...

title: An Invisible Sign
review: Agrelo bumbles the mystery and borderline insanity of the material. What should be a bold depiction of a frazzled mind is instead a bewildering feature with a tenuous hold on human concerns.

title: An Invisible Sign
review: A soupy, entirely unconvincing grab bag of unmotivated behaviors and unearned emotional payoffs, An Invisible Sign feels like part of some woebegone, misguided stab at indie credibility and image adjustment for Jessica Alba.

title: Angels With Angles
review: An oddity as awkward as its title.

title: Angels With Angles
review: An otherwise lame and overly contrived comedy studded with former TV stars and largely unconvincing impersonations of other showbiz legends.

title: Angels With Angles
review: Thoroughly hapless and embarrassing.

title: Angels With Angles
review: ...all sound and fury, not nearly as funny as [writer/director/star Scott Edmund] Lane seems to think.

title: Angels With Angles
review: The film overshoots its zany mark and lands somewhere closer to hell than heaven.

title: Antares
review: Antares is another nail in the coffin of brevity.

title: Antares
review: ...the movie ultimately feels oppressive.

title: Antares
review: It's just a chilly trip to the heart of nothing.

title: Antares
review: Spielmann ensures only that audiences will be seriously bored.

title: Antichrist
review: The Antichrist certainly looks dynamic and foreboding as lensed by Joe D’Amato, but given how it veers from scene to scene between orgiastic absurdism, freakout ceremonies, and solemn religious speak, its wants for more seamlessness and coherence.

title: Antichrist
review: The Antichrist is actually rather restrained as far as Italian horror flicks go, but that’s not necessarily a good thing.

title: Antichrist
review: De Martino’s insistence that ‘more is more’ results in a movie that’s both a pale imitation of the film that ‘inspired’ it and an overwrought standalone horror.

title: Antichrist
review: Now von Trier's trying his hand at the horror porn genre without abandoning the genital close-ups, making Antichrist a sort of horror porn squared.

title: Antichrist
review: O nico elemento que merece elogios, nesta cpia pattica de O Exorcista,  a bela Carla Gravina; o resto deve ser exorcizado de nossas memrias.

title: American Ninja
review: it has persisted because it so perfectly encapsulates in a single film the beloved cheesiness of a bygone era, when low-budget action fare still had a theatrical presence and ninjas still had an air of mystery

title: American Ninja
review: Hilarious, if true, that Chuck Norris balked at what amounts to maybe 10 minutes of director Sam Firstenberg’s 1985 film — C-grade Cannon fodder if there ever was, which is saying something.

title: American Ninja
review: ...the arms-length atmosphere [is] compounded by seriously low-rent visuals and Dudikoff's wooden (and far from athletic) turn as the bland central character.

title: American Ninja
review: American Ninja was still a compltely awful movie. But educational in its own awful way. Now when I see my next ninja movie I'll have something to compare it to.

title: American Ninja
review: So this is what happens to the support cast of "Grease"?

title: American Dresser
review: Ultimately, the most intriguing thing about the production is Billy Joel's consulting producer credit.

title: American Dresser
review: Despite a fine cast featuring numerous screen veterans, this is a cliché-ridden effort that quickly runs out of gas.

title: American Dresser
review: Though never disjointed, locations, escapades and people whip by as if fully aware of the film's 97 minute runtime; a confusing approach, given what is inevitably being driven toward is an uplifting message about taking each day as it comes

title: American Dresser
review: With its strangely flat ending and lack of anything else remotely unexpected, American Dresser tries to take us on an emotional journey but doesn't really go anywhere.

title: American Dresser
review: American Dresser bludgeons your chest open and clumsily strums your heartstrings with a camel's hoof.

title: American Dresser
review: Scattered and ill-conceived.

title: Bedeviled
review: A routine teen thriller with some deeply dumb plot points.

title: Bedeviled
review: "Bedeviled" ultimately embraces clichs rather the subverting them. The evil technology's up to date, but the storytelling's too old-fashioned.

title: Bedeviled
review: I really loved the concept but the deliver is all wrong.

title: Bedeviled
review: The whole affair feels tiresomely empty, like a horror with no heart. It should have been a short film.

title: Bedeviled
review: Directed by brothers Abel and Burlee Vang, this horror movie looks great and busts open a few old genre chestnuts, but it's also predictable, bland, and not all that scary.

title: Band of the Hand
review: ... mainly whack, splat and kaboom, with fast cuts to a rock beat. Miami vise.

title: Band of the Hand
review: It plays like a TV pilot filled out with a few cusswords and strokes of excess violence.

title: Band of the Hand
review: Dumb movies are with us always, but it isn't every week that we have a Band of the Hand. Flawlessly false, it breaks into the elite of the super-stupid.

title: Band of the Hand
review: Dullsville

title: Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever
review: I'm having a hard time believing the words as I type them but ... it's not that bad.

title: Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever
review: An endless barrage of bullets and bazookas

title: Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever
review: For many viewers, the big question may be not whether Ecks and Sever will get together, or why they are fighting in the first place, but why am I sitting here, anyway?

title: Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever
review: I guess not every bad movie has a cult following in its future. Some of them are just kinda bad.

title: Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever
review: If you must see Ecks vs. Sever, just go bang your head against the wall for an hour and a half. It would be the same effect.

title: Ballistic: Ecks vs. Sever
review: Kaos is so in love with pyrotechnics -- and so arrogant in his assumptions about his audience -- that in the first few minutes, he presents one critical car explosion without explanation, then has his characters discuss another one.

title: Backgammon
review: The film's musings on artists and muses tries to be deep but gets bogged down in tiresome booze-soaked mind games.

title: Backgammon
review: An uncertain drama full of attitude it can't back up with action.

title: Backgammon
review: Something is off from the first scene.

title: Backgammon
review: The new feature film Backgammon has at least one thing in common with its namesake board game: After watching it for just a few minutes, you're bound to get bored.

title: Baaghi 3
review: [A] much-too stretched saga, despite all the hustle-bustle...

title: Baaghi 3
review: Bronzed and shirtless, Tiger Shroff can outrun helicopters, tanks, men. What he can't outrun is the mediocrity of this film.

title: Baaghi 3
review: Baaghi 3 is a senseless beast of a movie that solely exists to rupture the screen in images of broken, blasting, blaring men or machines flying mid-air and slow motion.

title: Baaghi 3
review: Tiger Shroff does have broad shoulders. But they aren't broad enough to enhance the weight of a film as unashamedly flimsy as Baaghi 3.

title: Baaghi 3
review: Tiger Shroff's show all the way. He slices and dices through the opposition with the finesse of a ballet dancer. He seriously needs better scripts sometimes soon to do better justice to his enormous talent...

title: Baaghi 3
review: Unless you want to tear your hair out in frustration at the cinemas, duck this crazy cinematic missile. It's a misfire from the word go.

title: Baadshaho
review: The film comes off as old wine, in a not very new bottle, which we have to sip for over 2.5 hours.

title: Baadshaho
review: Luthria is extremely self-aware in keeping things old-fashioned and devoid of logic. But that doesn't make the film retro cool, it just makes it terribly worn out and jaded.

title: Baadshaho
review: The story is strictly bare-bones, a glaring fact that is sought to be disguised through the means of gratuitous chase scenes and meaningless banter.

title: Baadshaho
review: Perhaps the best moment is a competent cameo by Virat Kohli. Unfortunately, the advertisement he appears in isn't part of Baadshaho. To be fair, the long interval did bolster the pace of the film.

title: Baadshaho
review: The screenplay and execution literally steal defeat from the jaws of victory.

title: Baadshaho
review: Baadshaho has too many ordinarily written characters jostling for whistle-worthy one-liners for 136-minutes.

title: Basil
review: Next time the actors might ask to see a script first

title: Age of Kill
review: Will disappoint even the most undiscerning viewer.

title: Age of Kill
review: Kemp tries to be butch, with his grey slicked-back hair and war-worn features, but somehow you expect him to pick up his bass guitar and break into True or Gold. The rest of the acting is exceptionally wooden.

title: Age of Kill
review: This is truly terrible: a cost-cutting British action thriller with clunky script, wooden acting, uncertain directing, cheapo-looking interiors and the most outrageously obvious and rubbish "twist" reveal at the end.

title: Age of Kill
review: A film that fancies itself smarter than it is, but ultimately comes up short in all areas.

title: Age of Kill
review: Age Of Kill isn't just Taken, it's outright theft.

title: Attraction
review: Turn-Off would be a more appropriate title for Attraction, an irritating study of sexual obsession and voyeurism.

title: Attraction
review: Fails to capitalize on the fact that it will be found in the "thriller" bin at any video store.

title: Attraction
review: Even though it fails in every department,it seems that there might be a better movie buried in there somewhere.

title: Amateur Night
review: The film is peppered with interesting true-life details, but these are overwhelmed by frantic comedic sequences.

title: Amateur Night
review: Looks ... like a musty remnant from the old Cinemax late night programming block.

title: Amateur Night
review: The gross-out scenes and raunchy banter between the film's sex workers are funny, but its world is pretty small and unsurprising.

title: Amateur Night
review: Jason Biggs plays a failing architect who becomes an Uber driver for a trio of Los Angeles hookers, one of whom is played by Ashley Tisdale in a salty performance intended to distance her from the sweet turns she did in the High School Musical films.

title: Amateur Night
review: Never manages to feel personal, and instead is reduced to coming off as just another raunchy comedy.

title: Amateur Night
review: "Amateur Night" isn't wild or funny. It would rather spray its characters with vaginal fluid than dream up a killer punchline.

title: Alexander the Great
review: Robert Rossen has aimed for greatness in Alexander the Great and has missed honorably.

title: Alexander the Great
review: Overlong, over-written, and over-wigged, writer/director/producer Robert Rossen's Alexander The Great (1956) is a shining example of a lesser classical Hollywood historical epic.

title: Alexander the Great
review: The most notable battle on view in this picture isn't any of the skirmishes between Alexander's army and the opposing forces but the effort between Burton's blonde wig and March's shaggy beard to upstage each other in grievous grooming.

title: Alexander the Great
review: It might be a literate epic, but it's a long and heavy slog.

title: Alexander the Great
review: ...even more ineffectual and dull than Oliver Stone's recent attempt.

title: Air Strike
review: Air Strike retains elements of evident expanse and expense. Yet the final result is such a compromised jumble it's hard to tell what its full original intentions might have been.

title: Air Strike
review: Meet the 'Sharknado' of Chinese war movies: with US$65M worth of misery... and Bruce Willis.

title: Air Strike
review: How far from us are those times when Bruce Willis used to be in great action films. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: Air Strike
review: With a shoddy edit and a poor storyline, the only reason to watch the film is for its elaborate fight action sequences. Besides that, there's nothing more to look forward to in this uninspiring World War II drama.

title: Air Strike
review: There is no consistency in both theme and treatment. It feels like the director wanted to put every patriotic movie trope that he could think of in one film and exploit them all. The result is a mishmash...

title: All Roads Lead to Rome
review: The humor is dated, and while scenes in Italian without subtitles are confusing, it isn't difficult to anticipate the turns of story from miles away.

title: All Roads Lead to Rome
review: A combination romance, farce and road movie that whiffs in all three departments.

title: All Roads Lead to Rome
review: A heavy-handed rom/com centered around a Tuscan vacation to escape a stressful situation in NYC.

title: All Roads Lead to Rome
review: Apparently those roads are littered with clichs and contrivances.

title: All Roads Lead to Rome
review: Just as unimaginative as its premise suggests.

title: All Roads Lead to Rome
review: Lackluster mother-daughter comedy has teen drug use.

title: After Ever Happy
review: Can’t even charitably be said to be blah. It’s the space between the blahs.

title: After Ever Happy
review: After Ever Happy tries to tell us that #Hessa is endgame, but it's just a horrid tale of toxicity and pity parties.

title: After Ever Happy
review: It’s particularly frustrating to see Stephen Moyer and Mira Sorvino dragged into this mess because they’re talented actors who deserve better.

title: After Ever Happy
review: Though it feels repetitive and increasingly difficult to sympathize with their clearly unhealthy relationship, there's always just enough in each film to keep you watching.

title: After Ever Happy
review: 15 minutes of consequential drama stretched to a near-bust at 95 minutes.

title: After Ever Happy
review: The film is emotionally overcooked, full of cuss words and has some pretty dodgy dialogue that the spirited young cast do their best to sell. All credit to them. Still, it’s hard to sit through without wishing you could scroll through Google News.

title: After Image
review: After Image is many thing, but most of all, it's boring.

title: After Image
review: One almost thinks it was done as a joke, to see if someone could make a movie about a serial killer in which nothing ever happens.

title: After Image
review: It's not like the world's clamoring for yet another hopelessly arid serial killer procedural. Let alone one that stars John "Don't call me Cougar" Mellencamp.

title: American Anthem
review: The characters are laughable; the gymnastics are unattractive. There is nothing to recommend this film.

title: American Anthem
review: It's a pretty ridiculous story, and screenwriters Evan Archerd and Jeff Benjamin never figure out a way to generate any real suspense, drama or inspiration.

title: American Anthem
review: Unfortunately, as far as acting exercises go, Gaylord couldn't score a 5.

title: American Anthem
review: Essentially, American Anthem is an idea in search of a screenplay,

title: American Anthem
review: It's another example of how our most popular art form has been taken possession by what appear to be extraterrestrial moviemakers from the planet Stallone.

title: American Anthem
review: There hasn't been this much raw energy in a film since Rocky. On the other hand all that kinetic force is totally unfocused, leaving a pastiche of undirected elements that never forms a convincing whole.

title: Adventures of a Young Man
review: While the film has been executed with concern, integrity and respect for the pen from which it flows, it has a disquieting tendency to oscillate between flashes of artistry and truth and interludes of mechanics and melodramatics.

title: Adventures of a Young Man
review: I think it is a disgrace and a moral offense to take short stories by Hemingway and a piece of a novel and combine them with incidents from his life in a sentimental pastiche which is then presented as some sort of biographical film.

title: Adventures of a Young Man
review: There are a few virtuoso cameos, notably Paul Newman's sketch of a punchdrunk fighter, but Richard Beymer is too pale and pretty to be convincing in the central role.

title: Adventures of a Young Man
review: Based on Hemingway's short stories, Martin Ritt's chronicle is long, rambling, disappointing film in which Richard Beymer is miscast as the young novelist.

title: Adventures of a Young Man
review: Overlong, sappy and rambling.

title: Adrenalin: Fear the Rush
review: Adrenalin: Fear the Movie

title: Adrenalin: Fear the Rush
review: Sample dialogue: 'Over here!' 'What?' 'Arrrg!'

title: A Thousand Words
review: A disastrous comedy at times, with a few unexpected touching moments sprinkled throughout, A Thousand Words fails to come together like it should, and becomes a forgettable mess.

title: A Thousand Words
review: The idea of Murphy, that famously motormouthed actor, suddenly tongue-tied is not a punchy enough punch line to carry a whole film.

title: A Thousand Words
review: It isn't a horrible movie, at least not in comparison to Norbit from the same star and director, but it is a dispiritingly dull and cynical one.

title: A Thousand Words
review: While it's certainly not unwatchable, the mood is rather muddied and the laughs are never big.

title: A Thousand Words
review: One word will do - Sucks.

title: A Thousand Words
review: None of it really works though. Instead of garnering laughs it only serves as a painful reminder on how funny Murphy can be when given the right material.

title: Affair in Trinidad
review: Affair in Trinidad is neither as bad as advance reports indicated nor as good as Rita Hayworth fans would hope for.

title: Affair in Trinidad
review: The scenario, not only closely inspired by Gilda but also by Notorious and by Key Largo, is less clever.

title: Affair in Trinidad
review: ...an idiot rip-off of Alfred Hitchcock's Notorious (1946)

title: Affair in Trinidad
review: A senseless romantic espionage fails to recreate the chemistry that Rita Hayworth and Glenn Ford had in the noir Gilda, but Hayworth looks glamorous in Jean Louis Oscar-nominated wardrobe.

title: Affair in Trinidad
review: This tired tropical thriller is another attempt at making a Gilda.

title: Atlas Shrugged: Who Is John Galt?
review: Prime Mystery Science Theater 3000 fodder, cut-rate to the point of incoherence.

title: Atlas Shrugged: Who Is John Galt?
review: In 1949, when Warner Bros. filmed The Fountainhead, Rand threatened to burn down the studio if they compromised her novel. I'd like to think that if she were alive she'd be looking for lighter fluid for this one.

title: Atlas Shrugged: Who Is John Galt?
review: The prior installments weren't very good movies, and it should surprise few that this last one is the worst of the lot.

title: Atlas Shrugged: Who Is John Galt?
review: With virtually nothing that happens onscreen resembling human behavior or emotion to any real extend, the film can't even function as propaganda.

title: Atlas Shrugged: Who Is John Galt?
review: The favorite book of many young sociopaths you meet in business schools, it's all about a bunch of rich crybabies who don't want to share their toys so they break them and go home.

title: Atlas Shrugged: Who Is John Galt?
review: Both the cheapest-looking and most narratively deficient film in the series, a rather pathetic end to a project undertaken with more ambition than talent.

title: Ab Tak Chhappan 2
review: This kind of film can work if it has a new spin on an old story. But the cop who gets busy notching up kills, without making us wonder about the morality of someone taking it upon themselves to exterminate humans, is a cipher.

title: Ab Tak Chhappan 2
review: Ten years later, nothing much has changed -- informers and goons still hang out at the same hovels and bad guys are still caricatures.

title: Ab Tak Chhappan 2
review: Nana is as explosive as ever but the recycled script refuses to trigger any emotions.

title: Ab Tak Chhappan 2
review: Does Ab Tak Chhappan have any redeeming feature at all? Well, it has no songs. But, then, who would feel like singing when trapped in a darkened hall where Ab Tak Chhappan 2 is playing?

title: Ab Tak Chhappan 2
review: Sadly, Ab Tak Chhappan 2 is so terribly obvious in its deviousness, there's not even a smidgen of surprise to expect.

title: Ab Tak Chhappan 2
review: Despite its flaws, ATC2 can be watched, if you are a diehard Nana Patekar fan. On second thoughts, watching the original again would be a smarter move.

title: Acts of Violence
review: [A] slick and well-paced if uninspired time-filler ...

title: Acts of Violence
review: A gross, creepy and generally tacky piece of claptrap.

title: Acts of Violence
review: You can't knock it for false advertising.

title: Acts of Violence
review: What could've been a decent cheap thrill is really nothing more than a somewhat unhealthy way to kill 85 minutes.

title: Acts of Violence
review: If you want a dose of bullets and all kinds of aberrant acts, you can expect plenty of them in the film that, as the name implies, "Acts of Violence", is specially designed for it. [Full review in Spanish]

title: Acts of Violence
review: It's brutal work, no surprise there, but the production doesn't consider material deeply, going the urban western route, rendering the feature completely useless.

title: A Pyromaniac's Love Story
review: The cast is fine, the direction fluid, but the story wears you down.

title: A Pyromaniac's Love Story
review: A Pyromaniac's Love Story starts out like a lighthearted charmer, and then it goes on and on and on -- circling the same plot idea so doggedly that I began to wonder idly what it might have been like as a short subject.

title: A Novel Romance
review: "A Novel Romance" supplies a response to the question, "Is Steve Guttenberg still working?" but leaves unanswered the natural follow-up: "Why?"

title: A Novel Romance
review: Steve Guttenberg is probably supposed to be a lovable loser in "A Novel Romance," a drab, clumsy film by Allie Dvorin, but he can manage to be merely annoying.

title: A Novel Romance
review: The literary conceit [adds] tired self-deprecating narration and arch chapter titles to the romantic-comedy mix.

title: A Dark Reflection
review: Loraine directs at a very brisk pace but you can't help but feel he could have made his points more effectively in a documentary.

title: A Dark Reflection
review: Effectively an amateur feature film produced to professional standards - more or less - and directed by a former BA airline pilot called Tristan Loraine.

title: A Dark Reflection
review: Would-be conspiracy thriller undermines its own noble intent - to get the word out about a real-life problem with toxic air on commercial passenger jets - with its amateurism and dull, plodding earnestness.

title: A Dark Reflection
review: Unintentional jocularity and hollowness plague a script which attempts to construct dialogue full of technical terminology that also sounds appropriately urgent but it completely implodes in delivery.

title: A Dark Reflection
review: This tale is without the sufficient dramatic potential to work as a feature length film.

title: A Murder of Crows
review: Plodding and unoriginal

title: A Murder of Crows
review: A bit silly as a thriller.

title: A Murder of Crows
review: A mediocre murder-mystery thriller.

title: A Man's Gotta Do
review: Chris Kennedy's film isn't nearly as much fun as it seems to think it is.

title: A Man's Gotta Do
review: In this seasick, heartsick romp, a suburban Australian family struggles with love, loyalty and a fear that the patriarch is making his mortal enemies disappear.

title: A Man's Gotta Do
review: This amiable, off-kilter Australian comedy pits parental manipulation against adolescent pride, with generally amusing results.

title: A Man's Gotta Do
review: Lacks a coherent message, let alone anything very funny at which to laugh.

title: A Man's Gotta Do
review: Chris Kennedy's amusing comedy feels more like a 90-minute pilot for a TV series than a feature film.

title: 96 Souls
review: Beginning with a sensitive glimpse at the human-animal bond and ending on a note of social idealism, 96 Souls gets lost in the middle with an overload of sci-fi-inflected incident and info.

title: 96 Souls
review: All the trappings of no-budget filmmaking are present here, from the too-long running time (ten minutes shy of two hours) to the spotlessly clean, off-the-rack costumes worn by amateurish actors in impeccable settings.

title: 96 Souls
review: A scientist gains the power to read minds, but doesn't do anything terribly interesting with his new ability.

title: 96 Souls
review: Worst of all, it's boring. And that's the kiss of death for a film about super-powers.

title: 96 Souls
review: There's just no momentum to its story to propel these characters forward and the lacking tension really takes its toll over the film's two hours.

title: 96 Souls
review: It might someday achieve cult-favorite status among so-bad-it's-good aficionados.

title: A Dark Truth
review: A lightweight flick about a heavy-duty subject, A Dark Truth plays like a TV movie back in the days when TV wasn't worth watching.

title: A Dark Truth
review: For all the attempted intrigue and mayhem, the film is dullsville, mired by a poky script, unremarkable action and, the hard-working Garcia aside, uninspired performances.

title: A Dark Truth
review: A slog of a thriller that tries for relevance with an environmental message, A Dark Truth's biggest mystery is how so many "name" actors ended up in this torpid turkey.

title: A Dark Truth
review: The problem is less that it fails to deliver slick, larger-than-life mayhem on a blockbuster scale than that message movies generally play best to the converted.

title: A Dark Truth
review: This eco-thriller's message is an important one, but there are too many slow-moving scenes and too much screen time with characters just staring at each other.

title: A Dark Truth
review: Generic thriller has plenty of dead bodies, few surprises.

title: 9 Bullets
review: Though the screenplay hardly hangs together, both Headey and Worthington acquit themselves well; Vazquez, on the other hand, proves to be an irritating youngster.

title: 9 Bullets
review: Headey is never less than watchable, but what a wasted opportunity.

title: 9 Bullets
review: Lousy plotting and beyond questionable character motivations bring the story to a constant, grinding halt.

title: 9 Bullets
review: “9 Bullets” can best be described as a movie full of pieces that don’t fit.

title: 9 Bullets
review: Headey tries her best to smoulder and smirk à la Cersei Lannister, but her efforts become lost in this derivative and dull thriller.

title: 9 Bullets
review: Fans of the 1980 crime drama Gloria (starring Gena Rowlands in the title role) might be repulsed if they have the misfortune of wasting time watching 9 Bullets, which is a sloppy and pathetic imitation of that classic movie.

title: 365 Days: This Day
review: Absent even the thin, barbed hook of an imprisoned woman wielding her sexual power, the new film doesn’t have much reason to exist.

title: 365 Days: This Day
review: 365 Days: This Day is barely a movie. Its the emotionally bankrupt id of late capitalism, a braindead miasma of choreographed sex.

title: 365 Days: This Day
review: It’s piping hot trash.

title: 365 Days: This Day
review: Nobody’s watching 365 Days for any reason than to see Anna-Maria Sieklucka’s Polish ingenue, Laura, get railed by Michele Morrone’s alpha-roid mafioso, Massimo.

title: 365 Days: This Day
review: 365 Days: This Day distances itself from the sex-trafficking-as-courtship ethos of its predecessor, yet somehow emerges as an even more loathsome and vapid entity.

title: 365 Days: This Day
review: Sex sells but this franchise has proven that it can also be incredibly boring.[Full review in Spanish]

title: 8 Million Ways to Die
review: An oddly-paced work that is sometimes a thriller and sometimes a love story, succeeding at neither.

title: 8 Million Ways to Die
review: What happened? With Ashby, Bridges, Arquette and a script co-written by Oliver Stone, you expect the result to be better than a long drawn-out episode of The Equalizer.

title: 8 Million Ways to Die
review: How did Eight Million Ways to Die commit suicide? Let us count the ways.

title: 8 Million Ways to Die
review: Dreary second-rate urban cop drama.

title: 8 Million Ways to Die
review: Too bad that the gifted director Hal Ashby (Last Detail, Shampoo) ended his career with such a sleazy thriller that even the reliable and appealing Jeff Bridges can't salvage.

title: 8 Million Ways to Die
review: Considering the major talents involved here, one would expect to find something more than a run-of-the-mill crime thriller.

title: Action Replayy
review: What could have been a passable comedy, given the combined talents of Akshay-Om-Kirron-Rajpal in that department, never really gets a start. The lack of smartness in the writing shows up the absence of a plot.

title: Action Replayy
review: The movie claims to be adapted from a Gujarati play of the same name. I'm not sure if the said play had the Hollywood movie Back To The Future for its premise. This picture certainly does.

title: Action Replayy
review: The film is obviously inspired by Robert Zememkis' 1985 film, Back To The Future, where teenager Michael J. Fox had a similar job at hand. But must we need to tell you which one was better...

title: Action Replayy
review: Action Replayy promises us a fun romp through an iconic decade of the past: the 1970s. Bollywood in that era was indeed a riot and has been the premise of a few good retro films. This is not one of them.

title: Action Replayy
review: Bollywood time travel romcom has iffy gender roles.

title: A Beautiful Life
review: [Lau] successfully balances satire and sentimentality in the first half, but loses his bearings in the sappier second part.

title: A Beautiful Life
review: Whatever does work here - mainly a soulful performance by Liu Ye - ultimately gets lost in the excess.

title: A Beautiful Life
review: The film strains credulity by pushing its characters wildly to and fro with a shamelessly sentimental screenplay.

title: A Beautiful Life
review: Unfortunately, Lau throws in one too many wrinkles, squandering our empathy by forcing us through a long-winded relationship involving betrayal and illness.

title: A Beautiful Life
review: An amateurish, contrived drama that's neither captivating, insightful nor engrossing.

title: A Beautiful Life
review: There's simply not enough for Maggie and David to do to sustain an entire movie.

title: A Clear Shot
review: The whole thing might've held together with more consistent character work. Ignoring the suggestion that the 63-year-old actor might be playing an inexperienced cop, the elder Van Peebles brings plenty of heft to a middling character.

title: A Clear Shot
review: The way everyone behaves in this movie comes from hostage situation movies rather than real-life.

title: A Clear Shot
review: A Clear Shot is a clear miss.

title: A Clear Shot
review: Mario Van Peebles single-handedly imbues it with enough gravitas to make it somewhat watchable. Still, it begs the question: has he read the script, and if so, what was he thinking?

title: A Clear Shot
review: Based on real events, this hostage thriller has some timely, thoughtful things to say about race and (in)equality, but due to its low budget and its lack of suspense, it ultimately misses the mark.

title: A Clear Shot
review: Weirdly ambitious in some areas and far too low wattage in others, with Leisure unable to reach any noticeable levels of suspense as he wages war with limited budgetary coin.

title: 29 Palms
review: Not a good date movie.

title: 29 Palms
review: a morass of stolen plot points

title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain
review: Only small children with limited attention spans will be impressed by the lackluster kung-foolishness

title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain
review: Things are in a pretty sad state when Hulk Hogan gives a movie's most touching performance.

title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain
review: The franchise is losing altitude fast.

title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain
review: It's not that 3 Ninjas is a bad series -- in the right hands it found its perfect pitch of fun, funny, and thrilling action adventure for kids. 1995's 3 Ninjas: Knuckle Up is the series' peak. High Noon at Mega Mountain is the pits.

title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain
review: Abrasively loud, gratingly acted, appallingly directed and without a moral core, this "3 Ninjas" also boasts a screenplay with the most "Unhhhs" of the decade, that exquisite sound you make when trying to anihilate another human with your foot or a karate

title: 3 Ninjas: High Noon at Mega Mountain
365 Days
review: Come for the simulated bumping and grinding, stay for the ridiculous drama, stilted acting, hilarious soundtrack, and laughably offensive ideas about male and female desire.

title: 365 Days
review: There haven't been line readings this poor since the third act of The Room...

title: 365 Days
review: Thoroughly terrible, politically objectionable, occasionally hilarious...

title: 365 Days
review: This repugnant Fifty Shades knockoff plays like an erotic rewrite of The Unbreakable Kimmy Schmidt.

title: 365 Days
review: The Room meets Beauty and the Beast, 50 Shades of Grey and the stockholm syndrome in this cheesy erotic thriller with not a single positive aspect about it. Why such a product is Netflix's top movie of 2020 baffles almost everyone.

title: 365 Days
review: If you find yourself watching this make zero expectations. [Full Review in Spanish]

title: 10 Rules for Sleeping Around
review: A numbingly unfunny sex farce

title: 10 Rules for Sleeping Around
review: The movie doesn't work even as an instructional video.

title: 10 Rules for Sleeping Around
review: A dreadful sex farce with barely an authentic emotion, credible character or plausible plot point in its midst.

title: 10 Rules for Sleeping Around
review: One of those films of which there's absolutely nothing nice or pleasant to say.

title: 10 Rules for Sleeping Around
review: Fortunately, not all was lost. I did laugh four times during the movie. But that hardly makes up for the pain during the rest of the time.

title: 3 Strikes
review: Relies much too heavily on multiple repetitions of gags that aren't especially funny the first time around.

title: 3 Strikes
review: Butt-numbingly dull and almost entirely laugh-free.

title: 3 Strikes
review: Unoriginal and insulting, 3 Strikes goes down without scoring a single chuckle.

title: 3 Strikes
review: It would be easier to forgive some of the film's excesses, however, if it were actually funny.

title: 3 Strikes
review: Embarrassingly slipshod comedy tripe.
